cols = ['Construction costs (USD/MWh)','Refurbishment costs (USD/MWh)','Decommissioning costs (USD/MWh)','Total capital costs (USD/MWh)',
            'Operations & maintenance costs (USD/MWh)','Fuel costs (th) (USD/MWh)','Fuel costs (el) (USD/MWh)','Carbon price (USD/ton)',
            'Carbon costs (USD/MWh)','Heat price (USD/MWh)','CHP heat revenues (USD/MWh)','Discount rate','LCOE (USD/MWh)']
    
def addlabels(plt , df):
    for i, v in enumerate(cols):
    #     print(i + " " + v + ' ' + str(df_coal_median[v].values[0]))
        plt.text(i*0.04 - 0.24,2, 
                       v + ' ' + str(df[v].values[0]),
                rotation=90)

Solar is a popularly adopted source both at utility grade and small scale (residential). however depeicted in data is mostly commercial scale concentrated solar providers(100MW) which has high capital cost ( owing to high construction cost), but no fuel cost and very low O&M cost ( possibly due to repair of solar panels). 
The carbon price and heat proce like other renewable sources is still 30 and 37 USD per MWh respectively.
source.7aa32ca5: Hydro has larger LCOE than nuclear and wind ( which average around ~47 and ~70 MWh respectively ) , this is due to visibly high construction and capital cost. Driven by natiral resources ( water) fuel cost is none, although hydro too like wind has carbon price ~30 USD per MWh which needs to be investigated .
